1.translation: Concerning the faculty of simple drugs, it has been stated in another treatise that one must know the faculty of each, not only according to genus, as some have written—stating that they either heat or cool or dry or moisten—but rather distinctly and articulately, according to the order to which it belongs, as we have demonstrated. For some drugs produce each of the aforementioned effects quite faintly, others clearly, others strongly, just as still others do so completely. Therefore, it is not sufficient to know that a given drug heats or cools, but one must also determine to what degree it heats and cools. For all resins are heating, and this is a property common to them, but they possess no small difference in their degree of heat. Many juices, too, are heating, differing from one another by no small difference in their degree. For if you were to compare the juice of panax with the Cyrenaic and Median juices, the panax would seem to you to be nothing in comparison with them. And why must I lead the argument far afield, when we can recall the difference among those very things we consume daily? Dill, for instance, and rue and onion, all being heating substances, differ greatly from one another, so that in our therapies we will apply a sufficiently heating drug to a part that has been sufficiently cooled, a moderately heating one to a part that has deviated slightly from its natural state, and, just so, the most violently heating one to a part that has been very severely chilled. It is with good reason, then, that we have established four orders among heating substances, by distinguishing the ones that act clearly, the ones that heat very much, and the ones that do so violently to the point of burning, from those that heat only to a small degree.

5. On the strongly cleansing drugs. That these belong to the same class as those previously mentioned—those employed for cleansing moderately in hollow, clean, uncomplicated ulcers, and in no way biting—has been stated above. Those that remove a great deal of foulness possess an intensified cleansing power, so that some of the aforesaid drugs, being fresh, differ from the simple sarcotics in only one respect, namely in the degree of their acridity. And some among the others as well, those that cleanse vigorously by admixture, such as the preparation called Isis and that of Machairion, which we commonly use, called the “Oily” on account of its mode of application. For when our aim is to make a sinus flesh over, we dissolve it with much oil and pour it in through a straight-bored horn, in the manner of a clyster attached to a swine’s bladder; we also use upon it the devices called pyoulkoi, for among these too, those with a wider aperture are serviceable for such an operation. It is evident that we render a foul sinus clean by using the drug more neat—that is, mixing it with less oil—whereas a clean one [we treat] with greater moistening, by a more liberal admixture of oil. If, then, there be any suspicion that a brief inflammation is still mingled with the sinus, let the drug by all means be dissolved in rose‑oil; but if it be without inflammation, [let it be dissolved] in oil, and if it tolerates without smarting the earlier mixture, let the drug be dissolved in that. Suitable for such use is not only this drug, but also Machairion’s and the Isis, and whatever other preparations my predecessors have recorded as becoming sarcotic for hollow ulcers when mixed with cerate.

In their qualities, the bitter substances among them are of an intermediate matter, falling short of those that are very fine-particled, yet possessing nothing thick-particled. Some of them, however, have deviated slightly from the mean, some with a tendency to heat, others with a tendency to cool. The substances of all of these I have discussed in my treatise *On Simple Drugs*, as indeed I have those of the hard-shelled fruits, among which are bitter almonds and pistachios. But of the substance derived from plants I make no mention at present, for I wish to go back to the beginning and relate when and how I made use of each of the things that have been devised. For from this I think that the talented among the young will be encouraged to get to know the substance of drugs by becoming eyewitnesses of it not once or twice, but many times. For the discernment of perceptible things is rendered precise by continuous viewing, and the greatest proof of this is that those familiar with them do not fail to distinguish twins who seem to us to be indistinguishable, but are not so to them.

It is best, therefore, to observe the substance from herbs, shrubs, and trees before it is removed from the earth, during its periods of fructification: when it is about to fruit, when it is beginning, when it is advancing, and when it is at its peak. For this continuous observation of them will teach you at what time one might best collect them and preserve them by placing them in dry rooms, so that they are neither roasted by the sun’s rays nor moistened by dampness from the roof or walls. And this would be achieved if the rooms are neither underground nor on alluvial ground, nor, moreover, have windows facing south under a tiled roof.
